A worst case release is defined as instantaneous loss of the largest full vessel in each affected process onsite.  For RMP purposes, only that release resulting in the largest offsite Area of Concern needs to be considered (i.e., the worst of the worst).  Administrative controls such as plant policies limiting vessels to partial filling may be used to reduce release volumes, but active mitigation systems such as control valves may not.  By examination of the site plan, it is clear that the RMP Worst Case Scenario is the loss of a full railcar, which would instantaneously release 30,000 gallons (234,360 pounds) of VAM.  A railcar is the largest single vessel, there are no administrative controls in place that would prohibit a full car, and the cars are typically spotted at least as close to the nearest fence line as any other vessel.

The RMP Guidance specifies that atmospheric release (evaporation) rates must be calculated  assuming that the released material spreads to an unconfined depth of 1.0 cm, unless passive mitigation such as diking limits the area covered by the release.  Since the railcar area is unconfined, this assumption was adopted.  The evaporation rate at 25 C is then calculated as a function of vapor pressure (114 mmHg), release area, and windspeed, which for subsequent dispersion modeling is set at 1.5 m/sec (3.4 mph).

These values are directly input to the vapor dispersion algorithms in each respective model.  Per the RMP Guidance, wor

st case meteorology (F Stability Class at 1.0 m/sec windspeed and 50% relative humidity) must be assumed over the duration of the release (the evaporation time).  Per the AFTOX User manual, the ground was assumed to be wet, which is supposed to increase dispersion distances; and surface roughness was set at 10 cm, which is appropriate for essentially open, flat terrain with scattered small trees and buildings.  The distance to the endpoint concentration of 260 mg/m3 is 6,758 feet.



D.Accident Release Prevention Program
The facility achieves compliance with the accidental release prevention requirement through our OSHA PSM process.  Critical components of the process are as follows:

PART 1910.119(c)  EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

The facility has had a Process Safety Management Employee Participation Policy in place since April 1993.  The policy discusses employee participation in such areas as: hazard analysis, operating procedures, training, mechanical integrity, management of change, incident/accident investigation, emergency planning and response, safety and health committees and I.Q. teams.

PART 1910.119(d)  PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION

The requirement to maintain information pertaining to the hazards of highly hazardous chemicals is met through the use of MSDSs.  Per the standard this is an acceptable practice provided certain information is contained in the MSDS.  Information pertaining to the technology of the process can be found in the reactor procedures for the Resin Plant and the batch slip for the Specialty Coatings Plant.  Additionally, to meet this requirement the facility conducts Hazard and Operability Studies (HAZOPS) to determine the consequences of deviations, including safety and health concerns.  Information pertaining to the equipment in the process is maintained by the Plant Engineer.  P&IDs exist for all regulated processes in the Resin and Specialty Coatings Plants. Additionally, there are individual dossiers on all pieces of critical equipme

nt which include information on: materials of construction, electrical classification, relief systems, ventilation, design codes and standards, and safety systems.  Maintenance of critical pieces of equipment is monitored through theMP2 System.

PART 1910.119(e)  PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

The facility has conducted an initial process hazard analysis of the Resin Plant, excluding the thermal oxidizer, in September 1993.  The Specialty Coatings Plant was completed in the second quarter of 1996.  The facility uses HAZOP methodologies in conducting the hazard analysis.  The hazard analysis is conducted by a team of employees with expertise in engineering and process operations and the team leader has had formal hazard analysis training.  As a result of the study, a list of recommendations are developed.  The recommendations are sent to the appropriate Plant Superintendent and are followed up on by the Safety and Health Supervisor.  Documentation of the hazard analysis and recommendations are kept on file in the SHE Department.



PART 1910.119(f)  OPERATING PROCEDURES

The Resin Plant has a complete set of operating procedures for processes regulated under the standard.  The operating procedures contain sections on steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems.  In the Resin Plant these procedures are kept in the Control Room for Operators and in the lunchroom for Assistant Operators and Material Handlers.  In addition to the operating procedure the facility maintains a set of Safety and Health operating procedures that address such issues as: Lockout/Tagout; Confined Space Entry, Security, Laboratory Operations and Contractor employees.

PART 1910.119(g)  TRAINING

All employees who work in areas covered by the standard have been provided with initial and refresher training.  This training is done under an Operator Certification Program which was set up to comply with the Process Safety Regulations.  Documentat

ion of the training is kept on file by the Plant Superintendent.

PART 1910.119)h)  CONTRACTORS

The facility has a Contractor/Visitor Safety and Health policy (SHE-3) in place.  This policy addresses all requirements under the Process Safety Standard.  In addition, the facility keeps records on all contractor hours worked as well as any incidents and injuries.

PART 1910.119(i)  PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW

Since the implementation of the Process Safety Standard the facility has not started operations that are covered by the Regulations.  Modifications to existing operations are covered under the Management of Change process.  The facility has a Management of Change policy (#277) in place and in use.

PART 1910.119(j)  MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

The facility conducts an inspection and preventive maintenance program of all critical equipment.   The MP2 System is used to track equipment and what work has been done to date.  Procedures for maintaining critical equipment can be found in the Paints Engineering Practices (PEPs) and General Engineering Practices (GEPs) which are kept in the Plant Engineer's office.  Training for Maintenance employees is provided on the job under the guidance of an experienced employee with specialized third party training given as needed.



PART 1910.199(k)  HOT WORK PERMIT

The facility has a Hot Work procedure (#109) in place.  Forms, monitoring equipment, and training has been provided to Shift Supervisors, who are responsible for issuing the permits.

PART1910.119(l)  MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

The facility has a Management of Change procedure (#277) in place and in use.

PART 1910.119(m)  INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

Incident investigation and reporting is covered in procedure (#176).  The facility investigates all accidents, not just those in covered processes.  Recommendations from the investigation are forwarded to the appropriate parties for implementation.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


A.	Statement of Purpose

The purpose of this Plan is to identify those incidents, such as fire, explosion, spills or air pollution releases that would effect the surrounding community and guide the response to any such occurrence.  Plant personnel are trained properly to deal with specific emergency response situations.  This Plan is written in compliance with the Risk management Programs under Clean Air Action Section 112(e)(7).  This location is covered by this regulation because Vinyl Acetate Monomer (VAM) is stored and processed at the Resin plant.

This Plan is designed for the employees of Glidden, Emergency Responders and the general public, and contains details of specific response actions and reporting procedures to be followed in the event of an emergency.  This Plan is the primary source of information necessary to notify local, State and Federal agencies for offsite releases of Vinyl Acetate Monomer.

This plan is supported of various procedures contained in the Glidden SPCC Plan, Health and Safety Operating Manual, Emergency Response Team Manual, Emergency Response Plan, Emergency Action Plan, the Plant Process Safety Program and various other plant operations manuals.

B.Description of Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

VAM is delivered to the site on railcars which may be up to 30,000 gallons in capacity.  It is stored in two 15,000 gallon tanks prior to being pumped to the Resin plant for processing.  VAM is pumped from the storage tank into a weight tank or reactor vessel inside the plant.  The reaction converts all the monomer into a non-hazardous polymer (latex).

E.Organizational Responsibilities

The Huron plant of The Glidden Company in keeping with Company policy will maintain an Emergency Response Team at this location.

The Team will be under the direction and training of the Team Coordinator.  Plant Superintendents and Supervisors will serve as on- scene coordinators.

Hands-on field training will be conducted at least annually utilizing all equipment expected to be used by the team.  Additional classroom / pre- planning activities will be conducted at least one time during the year.  Drills with the Huron Fire Department and/or the Erie County Emergency Management Agency are conducted annually.

The Emergency Response team functions will include fighting incipient fires, confined space rescue, protecting exposures from fires on-site or in adjacent plants, securing leaks and spills, providing support activities to the public Fire Department and other outside agencies and providing tactical guidance to the public Fire Department.  The command structure for the Emergency Response Team is as follows:

Plant Manager: The Manager is assigned overall responsibility to protect personnel, site facility, and the public.  The Manager will be available at the main control center for counsel and overall guidance during an emergency.  The Plant Manager is the Emergency Coordinator.

Incident Commander (IC): The IC organizes and directs the emergency control activities.  The IC's responsibilities include establ

ishing control centers and managing all operations of the emergency response action.  The IC will establish headquarters as close to the emergency scene as safety permits.

Emergency Response Team Leader: The Team Leader, along with the Emergency Response Team, is responsible for correcting the emergency situation as promptly as possible; this may include shutting down and securing operations.  The Team Leader also provides guidance to the Emergency Response Team.  The Team Leader communicates directly with the Incident Commander.

The facility Emergency Response Team Leader is also the Coordinator for the Erie County Emergency Response Team.  The Environmental Coordinator is a Committee member of the LEPC (Erie County Emergency Management Agency).

All fire and sprinkler (water flow), temperature, security and high level alarms on the Hazardous Waste tanks are monitored continuously by a third party security company.  The Sheriff and Fire Departments are notified by the security company.
